com.segment.analytics

Class Analytics

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.segment.analytics.Analytics
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    android.app.Application.ActivityLifecycleCallbacks

    public class Analytics
extends java.lang.Object
implements android.app.Application.ActivityLifecycleCallbacks
    The idea is simple: one pipeline for all your data.

    Use with(android.content.Context) for the global singleton instance or construct your own instance with Analytics.Builder.

    See Also:
    Segment.io

      static class  Analytics.Builder
      Fluent API for creating Analytics instances.

    • Method Detail

      • with

        public static Analytics with(android.content.Context context)
        The global default Analytics instance.

        This instance is automatically initialized with defaults that are suitable to most implementations.

        If these settings do not meet the requirements of your application, you can provide properties in analytics.xml or you can construct your own instance with full control over the configuration by using Analytics.Builder.

      • identify

      • identify

      • identify

        public void identify(java.lang.String userId,
                     Traits traits,
                     Options options)
        Identify lets you tie one of your users and their actions to a recognizable userId. It also lets you record traits about the user, like their email, name, account type, etc.
        Parameters:
        userId - Unique identifier which you recognize a user by in your own database. If this is null or empty, any previous id we have (could be the anonymous id) will be used.
        traits - Traits about the user
        options - To configure the call
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if userId is null or an empty string
        See Also:
        Identify Documentation

      • group

        public void group(java.lang.String groupId)
        See Also:
        #group(String, String, Traits, Options)}

      • group

        public void group(java.lang.String userId,
                  java.lang.String groupId,
                  Traits traits,
                  Options options)
        The group method lets you associate a user with a group. It also lets you record custom traits about the group, like industry or number of employees.

        If you've called identify(String, Traits, Options) before, this will automatically remember the user id. If not, it will fall back to use the anonymousId instead.

        Parameters:
        userId - To match up a user with their associated group.
        groupId - Unique identifier which you recognize a group by in your own database. Must not be null or empty.
        options - To configure the call
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if groupId is null or an empty string
        See Also:
        Group Documentation

      • track

        public void track(java.lang.String event)
        See Also:
        #track(String, Properties, Options)}

      • track

        public void track(java.lang.String event,
                  Properties properties)
        See Also:
        #track(String, Properties, Options)}

      • track

        public void track(java.lang.String event,
                  Properties properties,
                  Options options)
        The track method is how you record any actions your users perform. Each action is known by a name, like 'Purchased a T-Shirt'. You can also record properties specific to those actions. For example a 'Purchased a Shirt' event might have properties like revenue or size.
        Parameters:
        event - Name of the event. Must not be null or empty.
        properties - Properties to add extra information to this call
        options - To configure the call
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if event name is null or an empty string
        See Also:
        Track Documentation

      • screen

        public void screen(java.lang.String category,
                   java.lang.String name)
        See Also:
        #screen(String, String, Properties, Options)}

      • screen

        public void screen(java.lang.String category,
                   java.lang.String name,
                   Properties properties)
        See Also:
        #screen(String, String, Properties, Options)}

      • screen

        public void screen(java.lang.String category,
                   java.lang.String name,
                   Properties properties,
                   Options options)
        The screen methods let your record whenever a user sees a screen of your mobile app, and attach a name, category or properties to the screen.

        Either category or name must be provided.

        Parameters:
        category - A category to describe the screen
        name - A name for the screen
        properties - Properties to add extra information to this call
        options - To configure the call
        See Also:
        Screen Documentation

      • alias

        public void alias(java.lang.String newId,
                  java.lang.String previousId)
        See Also:
        #alias(String, String, Options)}

      • alias

        public void alias(java.lang.String newId,
                  java.lang.String previousId,
                  Options options)
        The alias method is used to merge two user identities, effectively connecting two sets of user data as one. This is an advanced method, but it is required to manage user identities successfully in some of our integrations. You should still call identify(String, Traits, Options) with newId if you want to use it as the default id.
        Parameters:
        newId - The newId to map the old id to. Must not be null to empty.
        previousId - The old id we want to map. If it is null, the userId we've cached will automatically used.
        options - To configure the call
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if newId is null or empty
        See Also:
        Alias Documentation

      • flush

        public void flush()
        Flush all the messages in the queue. This wil do nothing for bundled integrations that don't have an explicit flush method.

      • getAnalyticsContext
